Contact Us                              FAQ   Contact   Editorial Staff   Links                    Home » About                         Editorial Staff                                                                           Editor-in-Chief: Danielle Ofri, MD, PhD, DLitt (Hon)  Danielle Ofri is associate professor of medicine at New York University, and practices medicine and teaches at Bellevue Hospital. Ofri's newest book is What Doctors Feel: How Emotions Affect the Practice of Medicine . She is also the author of Singular Intimacies: Becoming a Doctor at Bellevue and Incidental Findings: Lessons from My Patients in the Art of Medicine , as well as Medicine in Translation . Her essays have been included in Best American Essays 2002 and 2005 , and in Best American Science Writing 2003 . Ofri writes regularly for the New York Times . Her essays have also appeared in the Los Angeles Times , the San Francisco Chronicle , the New England Journal of Medicine , the Lancet and on National Public Radio. She is the recipient of the 2005 McGovern Award from the American Medical Writers Association for "preeminent contributions to medical communication." www.danielleofri.com                                                   Senior Fiction Editor: Ronna Wineberg earned a BA from the University of Michigan and JD from the University of Denver. She is the author of On Bittersweet Place , which is her first novel (Relegation Books) and Second Language , a collection of stories (New Rivers Press). Second Language won the New Rivers Press Many Voices Project Literary Competition, and was the runner-up for the 2006 Reform Judaism Prize for Jewish Fiction. Her stories have appeared in American Way, Berkeley Fiction Review, Colorado Review, Laurel Review, So to Speak, South Dakota Review , and elsewhere, and have been broadcast on National Public Radio. Wineberg’s essays have appeared in DAUGHTERS, Ethics in Criminal Justice (Wyndam Hall Press), River Oak Review, Steam Ticket, The Tennessean , and Writers on the Job (Hopewell Publications). She is the recipient of the John Atherton Scholarship in fiction from the Bread Loaf Writers Conference and residencies to the Virginia Center for the Creative Arts and the Ragdale Foundation. She has been awarded a fellowship in fiction from the New York Foundation for the Arts. Wineberg has taught writing at New York University and elsewhere, and she is the founding fiction editor of the BLR . Her website is Ronnawineberg.com                                                                Senior Nonfiction Editor: Jerome Lowenstein, MD , a nephrologist, is a Professor of Medicine and Firm Chief at New York University School of Medicine. His full time activities include teaching, patient care, and translational research. In 1979 he founded, and continues to direct, the Humanistic Aspects of Medical Education program. He is the Founding Publisher of the Bellevue Literary Press. He is the author of four books: Acid and Basics (Oxford University Press, 1992); The Midnight Meal and Other Essays about Doctors, Patients, and Medicine (Yale University Press, 1997; University of Michigan Press, 2005), Henderson’s Equation (Gadd Books, 2008) and Zichronot/Memories A Journal (Mulberry Tree Press, 2012).                                                 Fiction Editor: Suzanne McConnell ’s fiction won First Prize in the 2014 Prime Number Magazine Awards for Flash Fiction and has been nominated twice for the Pushcart Prize, appearing in The Huffington Post, The Saint Ann’s Review, Bellevue Literary Review , and elsewhere. An excerpt from her novel won Second Prize in So to Speak ’s Fiction Contest. She taught writing at Hunter College for thirty years and now leads seminars in literature and medicine at hospitals. “Necessary Stories,” her piece about Bellevue Literary Review, can be found on-line at The Review Review . She has published memoirs of Kurt Vonnegut in The Brooklyn Rail and Writer’s Digest , and is currently writing a book, Vonnegut’s Pearls , on his advice to writers, to be published by Seven Stories Press. Her website is www.suzannemcconnell.com                                                      Poetry Editor: Jason Schneiderman is the author of Sublimation Point, a Stahlecker Selection from Four Way Books, and Striking Surface, winner of the 2009 Richard Snyder Prize from Ashland Poetry Press. His poetry and essays have appeared in numerous journals and anthologies, including American Poetry Review, The Best American Poetry, Poetry London, Grand Street, The Penguin Book of the Sonnet, Story Quarterly, and Tin House. He has received fellowships from Yaddo, The Fine Arts Work Center, and The Bread Loaf Writers’ Conference. He was the recipient of the Emily Dickinson Award from the Poetry Society of America in 2004. He directs the Writing Center at the Borough of Manhattan Community College. www.jasonschneiderman.net      (Photo credit: Star Black)                                                   Managing Editor: Stacy Bodziak holds a BA in English Literature and Psychology from New York University, and an MA in Developmental Psychology from Teachers College, Columbia University. In addition to her work with the BLR , she works closely with Dr. Oshinsky on the projects of the Division of Medical Humanities, including a weekly newsletter, educational activities, and events, and as the Communications Associate of the Department of Medicine.                                                                              Associate Editor: Monica Wendel is the author of No Apocalyps e, which was awarded the Georgetown Review poetry manuscript prize, and the chapbooks Call it a Window and Pioneer . She is assistant professor of composition and creative writing at St. Thomas Aquinas College.                                                                Publisher: David Oshinsky, PhD , is the director of the Division of Medical Humanities at NYU School of Medicine and a professor in the NYU Department of History. Previously, Dr. Oshinsky was at the University of Texas at Austin, where he received the university’s Raymond Dickson Centennial Teaching Award. He graduated from Cornell University and obtained his PhD from Brandeis University.               An accomplished writer and American historian, his books include A Conspiracy So Immense: The World of Joe McCarthy, which won the Hardeman Prize for the best book about the U.S. Congress, and Worse Than Slavery , which won the Robert F. Kennedy Prize for distinguished contribution to human rights. His latest book, Polio: An American Story , won both the Pulitzer Prize in History and the Hoover Presidential Book Award. In 2009, PBS aired a documentary based upon this work, "The Polio Crusade," and he received the Dean's Medal from the Bloomberg-Johns Hopkins School of Public Health for his distinguished contributions to the field. His articles and reviews appear regularly in the New York Times and other national publications.                                                                                       Emeriti:  Founding Publisher: Martin J.     Editorial Guide            Wondering how to refer to academic titles and degrees? For information on how to identify NYU Steinhardt in text and in your email signatures, see School Name . For style concerns that are not addressed in this guide, see The Chicago Manual of Style Online .    For spelling concerns, use the first-listed form in Merriam-Webster Online .    For information on how to identify NYU Steinhardt in text, as well as how to refer to it in your email signature, see School Name .    For suggestions on web writing format, voice, and tone, see Writing for the Web .    This page is a working document and will be updated periodically.    Academic Degrees Academic Names, Terms, and Titles Commonly Confused Words Compound Words and Hyphens Dates, Times, and Places General Titles Numbers Punctuation Students and Alumni Web-Related Guidelines       Academic Degrees       Do not use periods when abbreviating degree programs: MA, PhD, BM    Use lowercase when spelling out degrees: bachelor of science (NOT bachelor's of science), doctorate or doctoral degree (NOT doctorate degree), master of arts (NOT master’s of arts, master of the arts, or master’s of the arts)    Use “bachelor’s” and “master’s” as adjectives: bachelor’s students, master’s students, bachelor’s degree, master’s degree, NOT bachelor degree or master degree or bachelors or masters program.    When spelling out the full name of a degree don't use apostrophes: bachelor of science, master of arts, doctor of philosophy    Use “doctoral” with degree, “doctorate” without: “He received his doctoral degree from NYU Steinhardt. His doctorate is in English education.”    Using the word “degree” after “master’s” or “bachelor’s” is preferable for clarity: master’s degree. Do not capitalize in narrative text: “These courses will apply to the bachelor’s program.”          Academic Names, Terms, and Titles       Capitalize specific professional titles when they immediately precede a personal name (like Mr. or Dr. would be used): “Professor of Anthropology Jane Doe.” Capitalize as well as within narrative text: “We spoke with Assistant Professor Jane Doe about her latest project.” Do not capitalize when titles are more descriptive and general, rather than specific or official, even when they precede a name: “ The event will be hosted by former senator Jane Doe.” “This play was written by author William Shakespeare.”    “Dr.” should not be used in addition to a professor title: avoid “Dr. Assistant Professor John Doe” or “Professor Dr. John Doe”    Do not capitalize professional titles when they are used in place of a personal name: “The president has arrived.”    Do not capitalize professional titles when they follow a personal name or are used in parentheses, separated by commas, or follow a verb: “John Doe, professor of anthropology, spoke last Monday.” “Jane Doe, department chair and professor of education, talks about our approach to learning.”    Capitalize named professorships: “Mary Smith is the Carroll and Milton Petrie Professor of Fine Arts.” Always capitalize “University Professor,” which is a special university-wide title.     Capitalize the full, formal names of centers, divisions, administrative offices, buildings, thoroughfares, monuments, and other formal groups, as well as generic terms used as part of the names; do not capitalize generic terms used descriptively: Registrar’s Office, Office of Undergraduate Admissions, Office of Financial Aid, Kimmel Center, Bobst Library, BUT the library, the gym, the admissions office, the financial aid office    Use title case for course titles; do not use quotation marks or any additional formatting: “I’m taking History of Infectious Diseases in the Fall semester.”    Do not capitalize names of fields of study: “Jane Doe was hired to teach History of Infectious Diseases in the undergraduate program in biology.”    Capitalize “program” as well as the names of official programs: Liberal Studies Program, Core Program, the Honors Program. Lowercase “concentration,” “major,” and “minor” in narrative text: “His major is science education.” “Her concentration is songwriting.”    Capitalize full department names unless they are being used in a general or more casual sense: Department of Science and Technology, science and technology department; Department of Music and Performing Arts Professions, music and performing arts professions department.    Use lowercase for academic majors, minors, and concentrations with the exception of languages, which are proper nouns: “She is majoring in physics. His major is English.”    Lowercase terms for academic years: senior, graduate student, first-year student    Use “grade point average” for the first reference on a page (no hyphen, lowercase). Subsequent references can be “GPA.”    Capitalize named academic awards and honors: Nobel Prize, Guggenheim Prize          Commonly Confused Words       Welcome/welcomed: Generally, “welcome” is used as an adjective and “welcomed” is a past tense verb.       “Students of any background are welcome at the event.”    “She feels welcome at the event.”    “Last year, we welcomed seven new faculty members.”    “Students were welcomed by their advisers.”       Renown/renowned: Renown is a noun meaning fame or widespread acclaim. Renowned is an adjective meaning celebrated or distinguished.       “She achieved international renown for her research on the subject.”    “Professor Doe is a renowned expert in childhood education.”    “He is a renowned scholar.”       Premiere/premier: Premiere refers to the first public showing of a performance such as a play or a movie, and can be used as a noun or a verb. Premier is used as an adjective to imply top status, or as a noun referring to a prime minister.       “The movie premieres tonight.”    “Are you going to the movie premiere?”    “Our school features the premier graduate programs in the country.”    “The deputy premier was accused of corruption.”       Diverse: Only use to describe groups or entities: diverse learners, diverse classroom, diverse group of students, NOT diverse student, as a single individual cannot be diverse.    Theatre, NOT theater    Adviser, NOT advisor    Intersession, NOT intercession          Compound Words and Hyphens       Don’t use hyphens in the case of races or ethnicities, even if it is used as an adjective: “He is a Chinese American student.” “Several African American teachers will attend.”    A hyphen is only used when there is ambiguity, such as in the word “re-creation” (to distinguish it from “recreation.”)    Nonprofit, multicultural, fieldwork, email, eNews, editor in chief, bestseller/selling, fundraising, healthcare, policymaker/making, preprofessional: no hyphen    Use a hyphen in “after-school” when it is an adjective: “This year, after-school programs will take place on campus.” Otherwise, no hyphen, but put a space between the two words: “Let’s meet after school.”    Use in a hyphen in the following: first-come, first-served; actor-director; artist-scholars; risk-taker    Course work: two words, with a space in between    Hyphenate an adverb or adjective compound before the noun: lesser-known works, well-known author, first-hand knowledge, part-time study, full-time job, 5-year-old girl    Use a hyphen in “full time” and “part time” when it is an adjective: “Options are available for part-time study.” Don’t use a hyphen when it is a noun: “You may study full time.”    Don’t hyphenate adverbs or adjectives after the verb “to be”: “The artist is well known.”    No hyphen after “-ly” adverbs: “Curiously strong mints”    Use hyphens when numbers are used as an adjective (“21st-century education,” “17-year-old girl,” “3-credit course”); no hyphens when used as a noun (“In the 20th century,” “She is 17 years old”).    Use hyphens when spelling out numbers: “eighty-two,” “two hundred forty-five”          Dates, Times, and Places       No comma between month and year: “He graduated in June 2002.”    Mandatory comma after day in month-day-year construction: July 1, 1855    Don’t use ordinal numbers (1st, 2nd, 24th) in dates: December 24, NOT December 24th    Don’t use hyphen in narrative text regarding time: Between 1850 and 1852, from August to October    No apostrophe before “s” for decades: the 1980s, the eighties, the ’80s (full year is preferable to abbreviation)    Use an apostrophe instead of a open single quote in the case of an implied contraction: BS ’10    Capitalize seasons when referring to an academic term/semester: “I’m graduating Spring semester.” “Apply now for Fall term.” BUT “What are you doing this summer?”    Lowercase a.m. and p.m. with periods and put a space before: 4:30 p.m.    No periods are used in abbreviations of university names: UC Berkeley, NYU    Do not use periods in acronyms or abbreviations using capital letters, such as “US” and “NYU” and “Washington, DC,” or in state abbreviations such as “NJ” and “CA.” Only use state abbreviations in a mailing address. In narrative text, spell out the name of the state: “Let’s hear it for New York.” Spell out “United States” when used as a noun, but abbreviate it as “US” when used as an adjective.    Use a comma after spelling out the city and state in narrative text. “In Newark, New Jersey, there is an airport.”    Capitalize geographical region (“the West”) when referring to a specific region, such as “the West during the early 1900s.” Lowercase geographical region when not specific: “The storm is moving south.” Don’t capitalize nonspecific directional nouns or adjectives such as western or southern.          General Titles       In titles, capitalize all nouns, names, pronouns (including “our”), adjectives, verbs, adverbs, and subordinate conjunctions (as, because, although, etc.).    Lowercase all articles (a, an, the), coordinate conjunctions (and, but, or, for, nor) and prepositions (common prepositions include: about, above, after, around, at, between, but by, from, in, into, of, on, onto, over, since, through, to, toward, upon, with, within, without), unless they are the first word in the sentence. Use the Title Capitalization Tool to check your title.       Explore Our Undergraduate and Graduate Programs for Fall Semester through Our Website    As Enrollment Increases, More Students Study in Summer at NYU       In hyphenated compounds in titles, always capitalize the first element. Subsequent elements are capitalized unless they are articles, prepositions, or coordinating conjunctions: Seventeenth-Century Literature, Out-of-the-Way Neighborhood    Use italics for titles of books, films, TV series, artwork, plays, radio series, magazines, and newspapers, including “the” when it’s part of the title: The New York Times.    Use quotes for magazine or newspaper article titles, radio shows, song titles, and book chapters.    Don’t italicize the titles of websites, online-only publications, or blogs (unless the blog is the online counterpart of a print publication, such as the website for The New Yorker ). Use quotes for titles of online articles and blog entries: Her article, “A Guide to Climate Change,” recently appeared in Salon.    Don’t italicize the names of networks (CNN, ABC)    Capitalize “the” in a title: “He subscribes to The New York Times .”    Use “the” before the name of an institution, always lowercase in narrative text: “Maria attended the City University of New York.”    Write out the name of a company the way that the company does it (usually found at the bottom of the hompage on the company's website). Use an ampersand only if the company's official name includes one: “AT&T.” There's no no need to include “Inc.” or “LLC.”          Numbers       Spell out numbers one through nine, except in the case of ages. Spell out any number that begins a sentence.    Use numerals for 10 and up, except when at the beginning of a sentence.    Numbers at the beginning of the sentence are spelled out, unless they are a percentage: “Seventy-five academic majors are available for undergraduates.” “85 percent of graduates are now working in the field.” Use numerals for percentages, and spell out the word "percent" in narrative text.    Ratios: use “2-to-1” and “student-to-faculty ratio” in narrative text, “2:1” or “student-faculty ratio” in display copy.    Use numerals for academic credits: “This is a 3-credit course.” “The major requires 42 credits.”    Use dollar symbols in text: “The renovation cost $30 million.”    Use comma after thousands in a numeral: 3,210    Use hyphens when numbers are used as an adjective (“21st-century education,” “17-year-old girl”); no hyphens when used as a noun (“In the 20th century,” “She is 17 years old.”)    When spelling out numbers under 100, use hyphens, even when they are used as a noun: “One hundred and sixty-four years ago was the coldest winter in the city’s history.”    In phone numbers, use hyphens: 212-992-7650. Do not include the “1” that needs to be dialed before the area code.          Punctuation       PERIODS: There is only one space after a period. Not two.    COMMAS: Use the serial/Oxford comma before conjunctions (and, or).       “Would you like a donut, a cookie, a muffin, or all three?”    “The Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development”       N-DASH (–): For parenthetical remarks. Use one space before and after (MS Word will automatically make an N-dash when you type two dashes between two words, separated by spaces). Do not overuse.       “We enroll nearly 6,400 students each year – 2,500 undergraduates and 3,900 master’s – to create a highly diverse mix of students.”       POSSESSIVES: The possessive of singular nouns, including ones that end in an s, is formed by the addition of an apostrophe and the letter s.      the School’s faculty, Charles’s research projects       The possessive of plural nouns, including ones that end in an s, is formed by the addition of an apostrophe only.      the puppies’ tails, the children’s desks          “Its” shows ownership of something, means “belonging to it” or “of it,” and does not have an apostrophe. Like “his,” ‘yours,” and “hers,” “its” is a possessive pronoun.       “The puppy wagged its tail.”    “The school is designing its website.”       “It’s” is not a possessive, but is a contraction, or a shortened version, of “it is” or “it has.”       “It’s been a pleasure to meet you.”    “It’s been warm all month, but today it’s getting cold.”       QUOTATION MARKS: Commas and periods and other punctuation that are part of the citation, such as exclamation points and question marks, always go inside end quotes.       “You’re late!” she said. “I am?” he asked. “Yes, you are,” she said. “Forty minutes late.”       SEMICOLONS: In sentences featuring series with commas within the elements, use semicolons to separate elements before “and.”      “Students come from Guangzhou, China; Houston, Texas; and Paris, France.”       Semicolons can also be used to join two related, full sentences.      “He was running late that morning; his friend was going to be angry about the muffins.”          COLONS: Use one space after colons before continuing text. If what follows the colon is an independent clause (it could stand alone as a complete sentence), capitalize the first word.       “It was obvious: The muffins would not be done on time.”    “There were three things that would not be done: the muffins, the donuts, and the cookies.”             Students and Alumni       An alumnus or alumna is anyone who attended NYU for at least one semester. A graduate earned a degree from the school.       alumni: used for plural masculine or for a plural group of men and women    alumnus: male, singular    alumna: female, singular    alumnae: used for plural feminine    alum and alums: used only casually/informally       When referring to alumni and specifying the year of graduation and degree, put the degree first, followed by the year, in parentheses: “John Doe (BS ’89) recently finished his first film.” The person’s program of study can be included in the parentheses if needed: “Jane Doe (MA ’99, Early Childhood Education) is currently working at the Department of Education.”    When only specifying the year, there’s no need for parentheses: “John Doe ’04 was elected co-chair.”    If you are specifying a current student’s program of study, you may choose not to mention the year: “Jane Doe, an Instrumental Performance student, will perform next Monday.”    When writing about alumni from multiple NYU schools, specify the year of graduation and the school of study: “John Doe (Steinhardt ’07) lives in Oakland, California.” “The conference will be led by Jane Doe (GSAS ’11).”    Capitalize “class” when referring to a specific graduating class: the Class of 2014.          Web-Related Guidelines    See Writing for the Web for additional guidelines.       email, internet, online: lowercase unless at start of sentence    website, webpage, homepage: one word, lowercase unless at start of sentence    eNews, email: no hyphen    Do not use ampersands (&), instead, spell out “and." (Only use an ampersand when it is part of an official name, such as "AT&T.")    Spell out abbreviations and acronyms the first time you use them on each page, even if they’ve already been spelled out on the homepage.    When linking to a website, use text that describes it: “For information, visit Financial Aid .” Avoid using non-descriptive text like “For information, click here .” (Do not include punctuation marks such as commas and periods in the hyperlink.) Avoid using the website address itself as the linked text: “For information, go to http://steinhardt.nyu.edu/financialaid .”    When writing for a print publication, underline or boldface website addresses and don’t include the “http://,” as it’s redundant. Example: “For more information, go to steinhardt.nyu.edu .” There is usually no need to include the “www” in the website address either, unless it isn’t intuitively clear that it is a web link, such as “last.fm”.)       Note: On writing text for links: . See more tips regarding links .       When linking to a website, use text that describes it: “For information, visit Financial Aid .” Avoid using generic or non-descriptive text like “For information, click to read .” (Do not include punctuation marks such as commas and periods in the hyperlink.)    Using phrases like " click here " is:       redundant : as web users, we already know what to do when we see linked text    inaccessible : it doesn't visually stand out on a page, won't be scanned by screen readers for the visually impaired, and is not descriptive enough to be "seen" by search engines    outdated : these days, web readers are more likely to swipe or tap than click       Avoid using the website address itself as the linked text : “For information, go to http://steinhardt.nyu.edu/financialaid .”    Do This:       Visit Financial Aid    Apply Now    Find out more about Steinhardt's graduate programs       Don't Do This:       Visit Financial Aid at http://steinhardt.nyu.edu/financialaid    To apply now, click here    Find out more about Steinhardt's graduate programs                          This site, and all its contents, are Copyright ©        by New York University.
